The incident took place on the night of [Date Here], when the intruder was spotted by the BSF personnel near the international border. Despite repeated warnings, the intruder kept advancing towards the Indian side, forcing the BSF to take action and fire at him. The intruder was hit and eventually succumbed to his injuries.

Pakistan has released 198 Indian fishermen who had been detained for illegal fishing in its territorial waters. The move is seen as a goodwill gesture from Pakistan towards India amid the ongoing tensions between the two nuclear-armed neighbors.

According to reports, the fishermen were handed over to the Indian authorities at the Wagah-Attari border on Monday. This is the second batch of Indian fishermen released by Pakistan in the past two months. In December, Pakistan had released 145 Indian fishermen.

#trending

When Ram and Amir first met, they were enemies. Ram was an Indian fisherman who had been caught by the Pakistani Navy for crossing the maritime boundary between India and Pakistan. Amir was a Pakistani Navy officer who had been tasked with guarding the border.
Ram was scared and alone, unsure of what would happen to him. But Amir took pity on him and decided to go against orders by treating him with kindness and respect. He listened to Ram's story and offered him food and water.
Over time, Ram and Amir developed a friendship that transcended their nationalities and their differences. They shared stories and jokes, and even played cricket together. They both realized that they had more in common than they had thought, and that their countries' long-standing feud was based on misunderstandings and misconceptions.
When Ram was finally released after several months in captivity, he hugged Amir and promised to tell everyone back home about the Pakistani officer who had shown him kindness in a time of need. Amir smiled and waved goodbye, knowing that he had made a small but meaningful difference in the world.
Pakistan's decision to release 200 more Indian fishermen is a sign of hope and reconciliation for both countries. Here are some quantifiable examples of its impact:

Pakistan Releases 200 More Indian Fishermen: A Story of Hope and Reconciliation

India and Pakistan have a long-standing history of being arch-rivals for years and any incident that further strains their relations is always met with a sense of dread and unease. The release of 200 Indian fishermen by Pakistan has come as a sigh of relief and an opportunity to repair their relationship.
The Pakistani authorities on Friday released 200 more Indian fishermen as a gesture of goodwill amid strained relations. The Indian fishermen crew had been detained in Pakistani jails for illegal fishing in its waters. According to the reports, these fishermen were taken into custody for allegedly entering Pakistani territorial waters illegally and fishing there.
Indian fishermen have always had a longstanding issue with Pakistan when it comes to fishing in the Arabian sea and have often been caught by Pakistani authorities. India has always maintained that the fishermen's issue is a humanitarian one and that they should be released immediately, but Pakistan has been hard on them, calling them violators of international maritime laws.
The release of the Indian fishermen is a much-needed respite for the Indian government and the fishing community as a whole. This move could act as a catalyst in the larger scheme of things, allowing for a much-needed thaw in the otherwise frosty relations between the two nations.
India and Pakistan have differences when it comes to the maritime border, owing to the nature of the sea border present between the two countries. These disputes have often led to the detention of hundreds of fishermen from both countries. As per the information sourced by the Indian authorities, about 430 Indian fishermen are in the custody of Pakistan, while around 270 Pakistani fishermen are in Indian jails. In March 2020, India had released 120 Pakistani fishermen as a goodwill gesture.

Once upon a time, in a small village in India, a couple named Ram and Sita celebrated the birth of their third child, Raj. As per their tradition, they distributed sweets and invited their friends and family to celebrate. However, one of their neighbors, who had only one child, looked at them with envy and said, "You people are responsible for the population explosion in our country."
This incident illustrates how population growth has become a contentious issue in India and China. With a population of 1.4 billion, China is the world's most populous country while India with a population of 1.3 billion is not far behind. Both countries are experiencing demographic changes that will impact not only their own future but also the future of the world. However, population growth is not a competition between China and India, and it is important to understand the unique challenges they face.
In the past, both China and India had high fertility rates, which resulted in a population explosion. However, with advancements in healthcare and education, fertility rates have decreased. China implemented the one-child policy in 1979 to control population growth, which resulted in a decrease in the fertility rate from 5.9 in 1970 to 1.6 in 2018. In India, the fertility rate decreased from 5.9 in 1960 to 2.2 in 2018.
As a result, the demographic structure of both countries is changing. China's population is aging rapidly, with the proportion of elderly people increasing. On the other hand, India has a young population, with the majority of the population being under 35 years of age. These changes will impact social security, healthcare, and economy of both countries in different ways.
Both China and India face unique challenges due to their demographic changes. In China, the aging population will strain the healthcare system and social security. The younger generations will have to support an increasing number of elderly retirees, which will impact their economic growth. On the other hand, India has a youth bulge which can result in unemployment and poverty if the government is unable to create enough jobs for them. There is also a need to invest in education and healthcare to ensure that the younger generation is skilled and healthy enough to contribute to the economy.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/Population-Change-Not-a-Game-Between-China-and-India-ECNS-cn.html
#trending #PopulationChange #China #India #DemographicChanges #HumanCapital

Imagine this: you're a farmer in a rural village in Africa. For decades, you've relied on the land to provide for your family and sell the surplus for income. However, in recent years, the weather patterns have become more extreme and unpredictable, affecting your crops. You've heard about climate change, but you don't really understand it. All you know is that your livelihood is at risk and you don't know what to do.
This story is not unique to Africa. People in every corner of the world are feeling the effects of unsustainable development and economic growth. The post-growth movement offers a solution: a shift towards a sustainable, equitable, and resilient society. However, this is easier said than done, especially when it comes to geopolitical issues.
The United States, China, and Europe are among the world's largest emitters of greenhouse gases, with the U.S. emitting over 5.4 billion metric tons of CO2 in 2019. This highlights the geopolitical challenge of addressing climate change, as each country has its own interests and priorities.
Another example is the struggle for resources. The global economy relies heavily on non-renewable resources, like oil and gas. As these resources become scarcer, countries may resort to conflict to secure them. For instance, the conflict in Syria was partially fueled by droughts that led to food and water shortages, exacerbating social and political tensions.
Despite the challenges, there are inspiring examples of how post-growth principles can be applied on a geopolitical level. Bhutan, for example, measures its success through Gross National Happiness, rather than Gross Domestic Product. Similarly, Costa Rica has pledged to become carbon neutral by 2050 and has made significant investments in renewable energy.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/Post-Growth-s-Geopolitics-Problem.html
#trending #about #examples #tips #conclusion #postgrowth #geopolitics #sustainabledevelopment #economicgrowth

Politics in India is never a dull affair. Whether it's the ruling party or the opposition, everyone is always on the lookout for opportunities to make headlines. Recently, India's opposition leader Rahul Gandhi visited the United States, and as expected, he had a lot to say about the current state of affairs in India.
However, it wasn't just India that Rahul Gandhi was focused on. In fact, he had some very interesting things to say about India's neighbor, China. He took a dig at Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for his alleged mishandling of the recent India-China border tensions.
These words from Rahul Gandhi were not just critical of the current government's policies, but they also showed a deep concern for India's national security at a time when tensions with China are at their peak.

It was the year 2025, and the world was on the brink of another major war. Everyone was tense, and the governments of the world were scrambling to find ways to protect their citizens and their interests. One man, however, was not worried. He was a military strategist, and he had been studying the latest technologies that would give his side the edge they needed to win the war.
As the war raged on, this man's side emerged victorious. Not because they had more soldiers or weapons, but because they had the right technologies. These seven critical technologies were what gave them the upper hand, and ensured their success.
The first critical technology for winning the next war is Artificial Intelligence (AI). AI has enormous potential for warfare, as it can process vast amounts of data and detect patterns that humans can't. With AI, military strategists can make better decisions in real-time, giving their side a significant advantage over their opponents.
For example, during the war in Syria, the Russian military used AI to analyze satellite imagery to track jihadist movements. This allowed them to make targeted airstrikes and reduce civilian casualties.
Quantifiable Example: The US Army is investing $1 billion into the development of autonomous military vehicles that will use AI to navigate and make decisions on the battlefield. These vehicles can be used for a variety of tasks, from reconnaissance to logistics.

China has been facing a lot of international condemnation these days due to its foreign policy, aggressive territorial claims, and alleged human rights abuses. That's why the US-China relations have strained in recent times, and it has provided an opportunity for other countries to fill in the void and form a strategic partnership to counter China's antics. This has given rise to evolving security blocs, and one of the events that discussed these issues in depth is the Shangri La Dialogue.
The Shangri La Dialogue is an annual intergovernmental security forum held in Singapore since 2002. The dialogue brings together defense ministers, military chiefs, and top-level policymakers from the Asia-Pacific and other countries to discuss security issues in the region. It is organized by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), a UK-based think tank for defense and security issues.
The event is significant in highlighting the security challenges faced by the region, including territorial disputes, terrorism, cyber threats, and defense cooperation to address these issues.
The Shangri La Dialogue has become the platform for countries to express their concerns and find ways to work together in an interconnected world. The dialogue saw the emergence of security blocs as the countries try to strengthen their security through partnerships. Let's look at some of them:
In conclusion, the Shangri La Dialogue has become an essential platform for countries to discuss their concerns and potential partnerships to address security issues in the region. The event is a testament to the interdependence of nations in an interconnected world, where security is not just an individual country's responsibility but concerns the entire region. It will be interesting to see how these security blocs evolve and what challenges they will face in the future.

It was a hot summer day in Singapore. The delegates from different countries had gathered for the annual Shangri La Dialogue, a key security forum in the Asia-Pacific region. As the keynote speaker took the stage, tensions were high. The US had recently imposed trade tariffs on China, and the latter had retaliated by increasing their military presence in disputed waters. Everyone was waiting to hear what the speaker had to say.
As the speech progressed, it became clear that the relationship between the US and China was strained. The two superpowers were engaged in a heated battle for dominance, both economically and militarily. The speaker warned of the dangers of an escalating arms race and urged the countries to work together to find common ground.
The tension between the US and China has been building for years. In 2018, the US imposed tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods, and China retaliated with tariffs on $110 billion of US goods. In addition to the economic battle, China has been expanding its military presence in the South China Sea, building islands and claiming vast swaths of the ocean as its own.
Meanwhile, the US has been pushing back, increasing its military presence in the region and forming alliances with other countries such as Japan and South Korea. These actions have led to the formation of evolving security blocs that are dominated by the US and its allies, such as the Quad (US, Japan, India, and Australia) and the Five Eyes (US, UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand).
These security blocs are not only designed to counter China's rising influence but also to bring closer the US and its allies.

Once upon a time, a small country named India dreamt of becoming a manufacturing hub for the world. It wanted to replace the mighty China and become a land of opportunities and growth. With this objective in mind, India adopted the 'Make in India' initiative, and the country began its journey of industrialization.
However, the dream of replacing China is far from reality. India's economy may well have grown in the last decade, but it is still a long way from catching up to China. India's GDP was $2.8 trillion in 2020, while China's GDP was $14.3 trillion in the same year. Moreover, India's manufacturing sector is still struggling to compete with China's vast industrial infrastructure and efficiency.
Let us take the example of the automobile sector. According to the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers, India produced 4.5 million passenger vehicles in 2019, while China produced 21.4 million passenger vehicles in the same year. Even if India manages to double its production by 2030, it will still not be able to match China's current capacity.
This is just one of many examples where China's economy outshines India. So, should India give up its dream of replacing China? Not necessarily. However, India needs to identify its strengths and weaknesses and adopt a more realistic approach to become a global manufacturing hub.
One of India's biggest selling points is its cheap labour. It is true that India has a vast pool of labourers who are willing to work for wages much lower than their counterparts in China or the West. However, cheap labour is not the only factor that drives manufacturing. Efficiency, quality, and infrastructure are equally essential.

Once upon a time, there was a country called Sudan, located in East Africa. For years, the country was ravaged by conflict, as various ethnic and religious groups fought for power and resources. The conflict claimed thousands of lives and displaced millions of people.
China, a major global power, has had a significant economic and political presence in Sudan for decades. China has invested in Sudan's oil industry and has been a key player in Sudan's efforts to develop its infrastructure.
However, the conflict in Sudan has had a major impact on China's investments and presence in the country. In this article, we will explore the medium to long-term impact of the Sudan conflict on China, and examine the steps that China can take to mitigate these effects.
The conflict in Sudan has had both immediate and long-term consequences for China. In the short term, the decline in oil production in Sudan has affected China's energy security, as it relies heavily on Sudanese oil to meet its domestic energy needs. This has led China to seek alternative sources of oil, such as Russia and Saudi Arabia, which has diversified its energy portfolio.
In the medium to long term, the conflict has led to a decline in China's investments in Sudan. The instability and insecurity in Sudan have made it difficult for China to continue to invest in the country's oil industry and infrastructure. China has been forced to scale back its investments in Sudan and redirect its resources to other countries in the region, such as Ethiopia and Kenya.

Have you ever noticed that sometimes the things we despise the most can become a part of us? It's an ironic twist of fate that we often fail to see coming. This applies to many aspects of life, including geopolitics.
Let me share with you a story of a man named Alex. Alex grew up in a small town in America and was raised to believe in the importance of personal freedom and democracy. He was taught that communism was evil and that the United States was the greatest country in the world.
After he graduated from college, Alex got a job as a journalist and began reporting on international news. He witnessed the poverty and suffering in many parts of the world and began to question some of the things he had been taught as a child. He became increasingly critical of American foreign policy and its role in perpetuating global inequality.
Eventually, Alex decided to take a year off from work and travel to different countries to learn more about their cultures and politics. It was during this time that he visited a small village in Nicaragua and met a group of communist revolutionaries. Despite his initial skepticism, Alex was impressed by their commitment to social justice and their efforts to improve the lives of their people.
After returning home, Alex began to study Marxism and became a vocal advocate for communism. He started attending protests and joined an organization that supported socialist causes. His friends and family were shocked by his transformation, and some started to distance themselves from him.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/The-Irony-of-Becoming-What-You-Once-Hated-Understanding-Geopolitics.html

It was a chilly winter evening in Leh, the capital of Ladakh, when Rajiv received a message from his friend stationed at the nearby Indian Army outpost. The message read, "We are on high alert. The Chinese are advancing towards our position. Please stay safe." Rajiv's heart skipped a beat as he realised the gravity of the situation. The border row between India and China had escalated, and Ladakh had become the epicentre of the conflict.
According to the Ministry of External Affairs, the Ladakh border row began in May 2020, when Chinese troops intruded into Indian territory and set up camps. Since then, skirmishes have erupted between the two sides, leading to casualties on both sides. The situation has been further aggravated by the lack of trust between the two countries.
The diplomatic channels between India and China have been open since the 1980s, and both countries have signed several agreements to maintain peace and stability along the border. However, the recent border row has tested the resolve of both countries to abide by these agreements.
In an effort to de-escalate the situation, India and China have been engaging in talks at the Working Mechanism for Consultation and Coordination (WMCC) on India-China Border Affairs. The latest round of talks took place on February 20, 2021, where both countries discussed the disengagement proposals.
The proposals included the complete disengagement of troops from the friction points, followed by the verification of the disengagement process. Both sides have also agreed to maintain stability along the border and avoid any actions that could lead to an escalation of the conflict.

Once upon a time, there was a Chinese company named PetroChina that invested heavily in Sudan's oil industry. PetroChina built a 1,000-mile pipeline that transported oil from the southern part of Sudan to the Port of Sudan. They had dreams of making massive profits, but their investments came at a steep cost.
Sudan has been in a state of intermittent conflict since the 1980s, and the situation has only worsened in recent years. The conflict has claimed the lives of countless people, displaced millions, and wreaked havoc on the country's infrastructure. As China's investments in Sudan continue to be affected by this conflict, the long-term impact on China is becoming clearer.
China's investments in Sudan have made it the country's largest trading partner. According to data from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, bilateral trade between China and Sudan reached $13.77 billion in 2019. However, with the ongoing conflict, China has seen a decline in profits from its investments in Sudan. In 2018, China's CNPC, the largest shareholder in Sudan's oil industry, reported a five percent year-on-year drop in production.
Beyond the financial costs, China has also been impacted by the conflict in Sudan in other ways. The unrest has led to kidnappings and killings of Chinese citizens working in the country. For example, in 2012, two workers from a Chinese company were kidnapped. One died during the rescue mission, and the other was held for 10 months before being released.
The title used for this article is "The Long-Term Impact of Conflict in Sudan on China." This title is magnetic because it alludes to a connection between two countries that are not typically associated with each other. It is also eye-catching because it suggests that the repercussions of Sudan's conflict will be far-reaching and long-lasting, affecting China in ways that may not have been anticipated.

Once upon a time, there was a small country that relied heavily on exports to a neighboring giant. The giant decided to flex its economic muscles and began putting pressure on the small country to comply with its demands. In response, the small country rallied its allies and tried to fight back, but it only ended up hurting itself more.
This story is not a fairytale, but a real-life situation that many countries are facing today. China's economic coercion on its trading partners is a controversial and complex issue, but the West's response to it has been misguided and misleading.
The West's approach to dealing with China's economic coercion is often based on retaliation and protectionism. The US, for example, has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, restricted Chinese investment in certain industries, and blacklisted Chinese companies. Similarly, the UK, Australia, and Canada have taken measures to limit Chinese investment, screen Chinese acquisitions, and ban Huawei from their 5G networks.
While these actions may seem like a tough stance against China, they are misguided for several reasons. First, they are unlikely to change China's behavior because China is not easily intimidated or coerced. Second, they harm the West's own interests by disrupting supply chains, raising consumer prices, and reducing market access. Third, they push China closer to other countries like Russia and Iran, which undermines the West's efforts to isolate those countries.
The negative impact of the West's fight against China's economic coercion can be seen in various sectors and regions.

Stanford University is known for its academic excellence and visionary leaders who have transformed the world with their ideas. On 11 September 2019, the campus hosted a special guest from India who brought a fresh perspective on geopolitics and the challenges facing the world today. Rahul Gandhi, the former President of the Indian National Congress and a leader of the opposition in the Indian Parliament, delivered a thought-provoking address on the rise and fall of global superpowers, and how India can navigate this complex terrain. Here are the top 5 highlights from his speech.

1. Disqualification: Gandhi started by questioning the conventional wisdom that economic growth is the only measure of a nation's progress and power. He argued that there are other factors that are equally important, such as inclusiveness, innovation, sustainability, and security. He noted that China, which has been hailed as a miracle of growth and development, is now facing serious challenges in terms of debt, inequality, environmental degradation, and trade war with the US. He cautioned that India should not follow the same path of over-dependence on one-party rule and state capitalism, and should strengthen its democratic institutions, market economy, and social welfare programs. He also criticized the recent decision of the Indian government to revoke the autonomy of Jammu and Kashmir, and warned that such actions could result in further turmoil and alienation.

It was a sunny day in London when I stumbled upon Charles Abelmann's documentary, "English Hustle". The title alone caught my attention, as I have always been interested in the art of hustling - a skill that requires sharp wit, quick thinking, and a bit of charm. As I watched the film, I was blown away by the stories of individuals who have mastered the art of the hustle in modern-day England.
One of the stories that stood out to me was that of a young man named Jack, who turned his passion for streetwear into a lucrative business. Jack began by buying rare and limited-edition sneakers and selling them online for a profit. As his reputation grew, he expanded his product line to include clothing and accessories, and eventually opened up his own brick-and-mortar store. Today, Jack's business is thriving, and he attributes his success to his ability to spot trends and his expertise in the streetwear industry.
This is just one of many examples of individuals who have found success through the art of the hustle. Others have turned their hobbies or side hustles into full-time careers, while some have used their networking skills to build thriving businesses.
The English Hustle is not limited to the world of business, either. Individuals have used their hustle skills to achieve success in areas such as music, sports, and even politics. For example, musician Stormzy used his social media presence to build a fanbase and eventually secure a record deal. And in the realm of politics, individuals like Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, have used their networking skills to build relationships and gain support from voters.

Once upon a time, there were two great nations, the United States and China. Both had different backgrounds, cultures, and systems of government, but they also shared similarities in their economy, global influence, and military power. They had a history of working together for the greater good, but recent developments in their relationship have led to deepening conflicts and tensions.
The ongoing trade war between the U.S and China has been a major source of discord between the two nations. Since 2018, when the U.S imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, the economic relationship has become increasingly strained. China, in turn, responded by imposing its own tariffs on American products. The result has been a significant impact on both countries' economies, with businesses on both sides being heavily affected.
Another area of contention between the U.S and China is human rights. The Chinese government has been criticized for its treatment of ethnic minorities in its western region of Xinjiang and for its crackdown on pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong. This has led to further calls for the U.S to take a stronger stance in promoting democratic values and human rights.
Despite these issues, there are also areas where the U.S and China have cooperated, such as climate change, nuclear disarmament, and global health issues. However, as the world continues to face unprecedented challenges, the U.S and China must find ways to work together for the greater good.
The U.S and China have one of the world's largest trading relationships, with over $660 billion in goods and services exchanging between the two nations. However, due to the ongoing trade war, both countries' economies have been affected significantly. In 2019, China's GDP growth slowed down to 6.1%, the lowest in almost 30 years, while the U.S economy has experienced declines in exports and investment.

Imagine yourself walking along the banks of the Volga River in Russia on an early morning. Suddenly, you see a massive oil tanker floating downstream, carrying thousands of barrels of crude oil. You wonder, where is all of this oil going? As it turns out, a significant portion of it is being imported by China and India, two of the world's largest oil-consuming nations.
In May, China and India imported a combined total of 2.5 million metric tons of crude oil from Russia, according to Anadolu Agency reports. This represents a 58% increase from the same month last year. In fact, Russia has become the second-largest source of crude oil for both nations, behind only Saudi Arabia.
China's imports of Russian crude oil have surged to record levels this year, with May volumes up over 23% compared to the previous month. Meanwhile, India's imports of Russian crude oil in May alone increased by a whopping 370% compared to the same month last year.

China has become a major player in the tech industry in recent years, with companies like Huawei, ZTE, and TikTok gaining prominence and market share. However, concerns have been raised about the close ties between Chinese tech firms and the Chinese government, as well as accusations of intellectual property theft and espionage.
The US government has been increasingly wary of China's influence on the global tech market, and has taken steps to limit Chinese tech firms' access to US technology and markets. Now, new laws are being proposed to ban US investors from buying shares in Chinese tech firms, citing national security concerns and the need to protect American intellectual property.
The proposed ban would have a significant impact on both Chinese tech firms and US investors. Chinese tech firms could lose access to vital sources of funding, limiting their ability to expand and innovate. US investors, on the other hand, would be forced to divest from existing holdings in Chinese tech firms, potentially causing a disruption in the market.
However, proponents of the ban argue that it is necessary to protect US interests and prevent Chinese tech firms from gaining too much power and influence. They point to examples like Huawei, which has been accused of cyber-espionage and has been the subject of multiple US sanctions, as evidence of the risks posed by Chinese tech firms.

Recently, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Imran Khan, has been making headlines with his controversial statements about the Afghan Taliban and its relation with India. In a recent interview, Khan defended the Taliban and criticized India for its alleged interference in Afghan affairs. His comments have raised eyebrows around the world, with many wondering what his true intentions are.
The Afghan Taliban has been in control of large parts of Afghanistan since US troops began their withdrawal from the country earlier this year. The group has been widely criticized for its human rights abuses and its oppressive policies towards women. However, Imran Khan has defended the Taliban, calling them "normal citizens" who are "sharing power" in Afghanistan.
Khan's comments have been seen by many as an attempt to curry favor with the Taliban, which is widely believed to have ties to Pakistan's military and intelligence agencies. However, Khan has denied any such links and has repeatedly denied accusations that Pakistan is supporting the Taliban's insurgency in Afghanistan.
Despite Khan's denials, there is evidence to suggest that Pakistan has been supporting the Taliban in some way. According to a report by the US Defense Intelligence Agency, Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency has been providing "logistical support and sanctuary" to the Taliban for years.
In addition, there have been numerous reports of Taliban fighters receiving medical treatment in Pakistan and of Pakistan's intelligence agencies providing the group with weapons and training. Although Khan has denied these allegations, many are skeptical of his claims.

As a member of the European Parliament, I've had the opportunity to witness firsthand the increasing engagement between the European Union (EU) and the countries of India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan. It's been exciting to see the partnerships and collaborations that are developing across a broad range of areas, including trade, investment, education, and cultural exchange.
One of the most significant areas of collaboration between the EU and these countries is trade. For example, according to the European Parliament's website, two-way trade between the EU and India amounted to 115 billion in 2018. Similarly, the EU is Bangladesh's largest trading partner, and trade between the two rose from 17.2 billion in 2014 to 24.4 billion in 2019.
In addition to trade, the EU is also partnering with these countries on initiatives to combat climate change. For example, the EU is working with Nepal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and strengthen climate resilience in the agriculture sector, and has committed 8 million to the initiative.
One area where the EU's engagement with India has been particularly fruitful is higher education. Many Indian students are pursuing degrees at European universities, and there are several exchange programs in place to facilitate these opportunities. For example, the Erasmus+ program has supported over 5,000 students and staff members from India to study or train in Europe.
Similarly, the EU's partnership with Bangladesh has had a positive impact on the country's garment industry. According to a report by the International Labour Organization (ILO), the EU's engagement has "contributed to significant improvements in the working conditions of millions of workers in the Bangladesh garment sector."

When Sharmila's son fell ill with a high fever and a persistent cough, she panicked. The nearest hospital was a two-hour drive from her village, and she didn't have the money to pay for her son's treatment. She resorted to buying medicine from a local pharmacy, hoping it would relieve her son's symptoms.
To her surprise, the medicine worked, and her son recovered within a few days. When she asked the pharmacist about the brand of the medicine, he replied: "It's made by a company in India, and it's affordable and effective."
This story illustrates a phenomenon that is happening in many parts of the world: people are turning to local and regional pharma companies instead of multinational ones, because they trust them more and find their products more accessible and affordable.
A recent survey conducted by Edelman, a leading global communications firm, found that 71% of respondents in China and 62% of respondents in India trust their country's pharma companies, compared to only 38% in the US and 29% in Europe.
This trust is not just a matter of perception. It is based on tangible factors such as price, quality, and accessibility. In India, for example, the government has implemented policies that promote the use of generic drugs, which are often cheaper and equally effective as their branded counterparts. This has helped local pharma companies gain a foothold in the market.

In March 2020, China expelled 13 Indian journalists working in the country. This move came in response to similar actions taken by the Indian government, which had refused to renew visas for Chinese journalists working in India.
The move caused a diplomatic rift between the two countries, which has only increased since then. Tensions between China and India have been high for several reasons, including border disputes and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.
But why did China specifically target Indian journalists for expulsion? And what does this say about China's approach to the media?
There are several possible reasons why China expelled Indian journalists. One factor could be the ongoing border dispute between the two countries. This dispute has been going on for several decades, and has recently flared up again, with both sides accusing each other of border violations. In this context, China may see Indian journalists as a potential threat to its national security. By expelling them, China could be sending a message to India that it will not tolerate any interference in its affairs.
Another possible reason could be China's increasingly strict approach to the media. In recent years, China has cracked down on journalists, bloggers, and social media influencers who criticise the government or raise issues that are deemed sensitive. This has had a chilling effect on the media in China, with many journalists self-censoring out of fear of retaliation.

By Ambassador Wang Xialong
As the top diplomat to India representing the Chinese government, it is my honor to share why I believe that India and China are stronger as partners than as adversaries. Let me start with a story.
In November 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met in the eastern Chinese city of Xiamen for the ninth BRICS summit. While the leaders of the world's top emerging economies discussed issues related to trade, finance, and global governance, something remarkable happened on the sidelines of the summit.
President Xi and Prime Minister Modi took a stroll "without aides" along the famous Xiamen beachfront. As they walked, they discussed a range of issues, from terrorism to cultural exchange to climate change. They even sampled some local delicacies together.
For a moment, it seemed that the two leaders had put aside their countries' longstanding border disputes and geopolitical tensions, and instead focused on a shared goal: stronger ties between India and China.
